entry.title: The added value of knowledge graphs in capital projects

link.title: The added value of knowledge graphs in capital projects

entry.content:
Value-add of knowledge graphs in capital projects, a new series.

This will be a speculative explorative article series on the added value of knowledge graphs in capital projects.

Moving forward with true digitalization where sharing is a basic ingredient, towards the specific, defining features of knowledge graphs, and how we can exploit those to create value in the project value chain. This includes the optimal way project (or intercompany) vocabularies can be set up, and current practical approaches like ICDD, CHIFOS, 3D data conversion to linked data and others.
entry.summary: Value-add of knowledge graphs in capital projects, a new series.

entry.title: On ontologies and graphs
entry.content:
Inspiration from an article dating back to 2018. Leading to the value of ontologies and outline for the specific use-cases for knowledge graphs

About ontologies and graphs in the capital project world

The article Where Ontologies End and Knowledge Graphs Begin posted by Spencer Norris, on the ODSC website sparked several trains of thought, in regard to the main theme of this blog, resulting in no less than three articles about the application of semantic technology in capital projects:

  • Does size (in this case of an ontology) actually matter?
  • Can you have one without the other and still deliver value?
  • Value-add of knowledge graphs in capital projects

These topics will be discussed in a series of articles. Follow the links to the respective articles to read more about the topics.__

I’ll include also some introductional material to graphs and ontologies for those not yet familiar with this emerging technology, as I encounter them on the web.
entry.summary: Inspiration from an article dating back to 2018. Leading to the value of ontologies and outline for the specific use-cases for knowledge graphs

entry.title: One without the other
entry.content:
The value of ontologies and graphs in capital projects explained

Introduction

This article is part of a series of three about the application of knowledge graps and semantic technology in capital projects.

The article by Spencer Noris brought me back to the time I started with semantics. The expert that was supporting us at the time said ‘do not bother with ontologies, make a graph as the first thing you do, that is where the value is’. And so we did, resulting in a successful project.

This article discusses the value of ontologies, knowledge graphs and the combination of both in capital projects, determining business values and promising options.

The value of an ontology in capital projects

I’m more into ontologies right now then in the mentioned past, and encountered in the recent past the question: “what is the actual business value of a ontology in a capital project environment?”. And given the fact that a significant amount of work in that project had been done on the ontology , it was surprising that finding the answer the question was quite hard.

Of course the usual aswers came up: the standard/unifying language that is created by the ontology. But then: standard for who? Is there actually something of a common understanding between project parties where a common language make sense?

The standard language argument

In general ontologies are a way to describe the structure of the reality in a domain of interest. In capital projects that quickly results in a taxonomy of the typical components used. The taxonomy can be structured along a system decomposition, a functional decomposition or other decompositions. Axamples in the capital project domain are powerplants that can be subclassed in single shaft plants and multishaft plants, bridges that can be subclassed as fixed bridges and bridges that can open and close. And then, of course this sub-classing mechanism is followed in the ontology down to a certain level of detail.

There are topics of interest with this approach: 1) The added value of this activity 2) The probability of actually succeeding in creating a detailled ontology that works for all parties in the project.

The added value

Most project partners are selected because of their knowledge of the project components that they work on. They will know what kind of bridge is being build, and are, to all intents and purposes, likely to be more knowledgeable about bridges then the owner/contractor is. In that case there is little value in constructing a project ontology. 2D plans (and now also 3D models) have for many years served a perfectly clear and regulated way of expressing the structure of a product including the knowledge behind the product (like how assemblies are defined). I argue that he added value of an ontology in these situations is limited.

Achieving a common detailled ontology

Ontologies are about decomposing general concepts in more detailled concepts. In the above example the ontology would contain a bridge, which is sub-classed or broken down to more specific kinds of bridges: fixed bridges and bridges that can open and close.

In earlier work in corporate envirnments I found that there are actually many of these decomposition trees, depending on the project phase:

  • In basic design, the functional breakdown often is a starting point,
  • In detail design a systems breakdown is usually followed
  • In purchasing the main division was in this case sub-contracts and bought out items
  • In shipping a division in break bulk material (things that you directly put in the holding area of a ship) and container shipping is the main division
  • In construction both the workbreak down structure on site and the machine breakdown are used

As a result information is reworked in every phase. The reason to actually do that is that the proces-step specific structure is an optimisation for that step.

Another that I learned is that project parties usually create their own breakdown structures anyway, because of their specific products: to them more detailled breakdowns are relevant (because they are concerned with them) compared to other parties in the project.

Given both observations I argue that the idea that a complete common language can be created is a little naive.

The value of just an ontology

Basically the conclusion here is clear, an ontology on it’s own has limited value. It’s only of some value to the organisation creating it, however there the concepts in general are well known, and, given the difference in the view on the products or parts of the project by the different partners, a common one is not an easy task, if it can be achieved at all.

The value of a knowledge graph

When made without an ontology a graph can still have significant value. When the thing you want to do is just use the graph for an application that shows integrated information about project components (the successful use case I mentionend above), a graph delivers immediate value.

The combined value

Combining a graph with an ontology creates additional value, as the ontology is the key to the knowledge aspect of the knowledge graph. Adding meaning to the data in the graph maximizes the probability that the data in the graph can be understood by multiple parties. As such, it is the way forward when using semantic data to exchange information between project parties. However to do that efficiently there is somewhat a bit more to that picture. Read more about that in an upcoming article about: so you have a graph, but how exchange information with it?
entry.summary: The value of ontologies and graphs in capital projects explained

entry.title: Does ontology size matter?
entry.content:
Is there an optimal size for ontologies?

Introduction

This article is part of a series of three about the application of knowledge graps and semantic technology in capital projects.

Recently I worked on an ontology that was used in capital projects for asset management. It’s size (measured in classes): 23.000, or in disk size: approx. 3 Mb of OWL data. This ontology was used to describe acreage objects. Some time ago I did some work on the ISO 15926 ontology, which (if I remember correctly) is in the range of just several hundreds of classes. The ‘world’ that is described by the ISO 15926 ontology is vastly more complex that the asset management use-case. A striking difference in size and content, but… does that matter?

Does size matter?

Well, it depends. As Spencer Norris mentions in his article there are big ontologies that deliver value to the users, most noticeably the gene ontology, which in size is even significantly bigger than the ontology mentioned previously. So. it’s not sheer size alone that determines the usability of an ontology.

What you actually want to do with it makes the difference. If reasoning over a data set is a target, then (as Norris mentions) ontologies are your friend, as they deliver a mathematically correct representation of the data, and allow reasoning.

If all you want to do is deliver information about objects in a domain, ontologies still help, but the bigger the ontology gets, the more difficult the understanding becomes.

In the specific case of capital projects, where limited time-frames are a fact of life, the difficulty of large ontologies actually works against value delivery. And as there is no actual need for sophisticated reasoning (in this use-case the ontology is was used to create a standard language between project partners), the size of the ontology is reason for concern. Keeping the ontology simple helps to quickly understand and work with it, which is a business target in capital project cases.

Analysis

The reason for the excessive size of the ontology was the amount of things that were crammed into it. Whereas ISO 15926 divides the ontology in two main elements:

  • a relatively small top ontology and

  • a relatively sizable reference description library, the asset management ontology contained both. Apart from that domain knowledge was also part of the ontology. Most notably the definition of the assembly rules of certain classes. It contained rules like this class is an assembly of a series of classes to describe the assembly of physical objects. To define that with only OWL as a language requires surprisingly large amount of intermediate classes and domain/range rules.

The actual origin for the complex set-up was found in the fact that the ontology itself was produced out of a separate system, meaning that, in the design state these complications where not noted. The resulting ontology was used as the unifying language between project partners and the owner. The project partners did actually experience the complexity resulting in extra costs charged to the owner for dealing with the complexity whereas the creating team did not.

This understanding, combined to the discussion in the One without the other article quickly leads towards improvement directions.

In this case a separation between the ontology and the reference description library was created to reduce the number of things going into the main ontology (this also provided a first step into the direction of modularization of the ontology), and the introduction of a knowledge graphs as a means to implement the domain rules was a second element to reduce the complexity of the ontology.
entry.summary: Is there an optimal size for ontologies?

entry.title: Interesting reads
entry.content:
Books, articles and websites

Updated every now and then. An excerpt from my Firefox synced bookmarks collection.

Books

These books are currently on my reading table.

Software Wasteland: How the Application-Centric Mindset is Hobbling our Enterprises, by Dave McComb
An interesting read about the quagmire where enterprise IT is now, and the reasons why it is so complicated to get out of it.

Controlling the Chaos: A Functional Framework for Enterprise Architecture and Governance, by Robert Fox

Knowledge Graphs and Big Data Processing: by several authors. Download the free book here. A broad survey of state of the art methods and techniques in the area of knowledge graphs and big data. Quite recent, published in 2020.

Articles

gist: Buckets, Buckets Everywhere, Who Knows What to Think?
A Semantic Arts Article On Buckets, Collections and Categories, and the way they’re used in gist. The separation of the different kinds of buckets is important for everyone working on ontologies.

The intuitions behind Knowledge Graphs and Reasoning
An article by Peter Crocker, discussing reasoning approaches in rdf graphs (alike the rule approach I discussed in my article ‘A taste of GRAKN’). Peter discusses RDFox, one of the rule technologies avaialble for RDF.

The datacentric revolution
An article by Dave McComb, about data integration on similar, but not completely equivalant data sources. My upcoming article on RML.io contains a practical demonstration of the descibed ideas.

The 10 Vs of Big Data
An article by George Firican, about characteristics of data in 10 dimensions called the 10V’s. Insightful for those who need to explain data management approaches.

Websites

Foundations of Semantic Web Technologies from the TU Dresden
Follow this link and open the Dates and Materials tab. An excellent introduction in semantic technologies.

Euclid
the educational curriculum for the usage of linked data. This website is an excellent source of information in regard to linked data usage. Download the free book, or browse the information online.

entry.title: The single source of the truth

link.title: The single source of the truth

entry.content:
What happened to the single source of the truth?

Introduction

We’ve all been there. The single source of the truth (or SSOTT). In the nineties, or possibly still in the early part of this century. And of course it’s appealing: make sure that data is stored only once, so you never have to worry about data consistency, synchronization and what not. And when you can, you should. Have it I mean. It still is the best option if it is available in your specific situation.

An inconvenient truth

In many cases SSOTT is simply not possible anymore. A typical situation is IT environments that result from corporate mergers. Often the source IT systems are that complex that merging the systems of both merging companies is simply too complex to be a viable alternative. Another reasons is the current agility of the IT landscape that results from cloud adoption and low-code/no-code application development tools. Yet another reason why the SSOTT is not achieved originates in the opposite of agility: the aging of the IT landscape: companies implement new tools that overlap functionality wise with older tools, just to stay competitive. These partly overlapping tools also create more than one source of the truth.

Apart from accepting the fact of multiple sources of the truth (MSOTT) and apart from the obvious technical solution of implementing a service bus solution to solve that problem, one sometimes sees that a radical decision is made to use only one the systems of the merging groups, to stay close to the SSOTT principle. That choice is often quite costly as well, especially if the other systems that are not the chosen ones, contain unique and valuable functionality. Which they often do.

Another situation where MSOTT is almost unavoidable is in IT based design factories, typical for capital projects. There a multitude of applications are used. Basic design and detailed design for example usually still require different tools to stay competitive in the market. Another reason the often met requirement of data delivery in the clients source system format. If the supplier decides to continue to use their own design tooling for the majority of the work, often a MSOTT situation is unavoidable.

Multiple sourced data: a reality

Given the fact that MSOTT data is there, and will be there for some time in the future: apart from SSOTT solutions we (architects, system designers, integration specialist, working in the capital project environment) need to have the MSOTT tooling in our belt as well. Possibly as an in between solution, but probably one that will be here some time.
entry.summary: What happened to the single source of the truth?

entry.title: A taste of GRAKN
entry.content:
Automated rule based discrepancy discovery by adding knowledge rules to an existing data set

Introduction

A typical situation in current engineering practice is the usage of a multitude of tools to perform the design work. A functional design system used to design the basic functional setup of an installation followed by a detail design in a 3D CAD system. In this case some of the design data will be in both systems (for example the size information of pipes etc.). Another example is document (-revision) information, where, during to the ongoing engineering work a central document management system stores versions of documents created in the design tools. There is a real risc that both systems do not ‘agree’ on the latest version. In these cases it is essential to be able to check for differences, to measure them and to report them, to be able to steer on data quality during the engineering process.

A complicating factor here is that typically engineering objects contain many design aspects, and one needs to perform the above check for each of these aspects. In this post I will present an approach that allows a fully automated check over all design aspects with a single knowledge rule, which greatly simplifies the above described problem. One thing to add: the approach described here is part of a procedure for which we filed for a patent, so when interested, please contact me for an update on the usage conditions.

The main reason to research and write this article was that, at the time we came up with the idea, we were sure that this could work. Due to production pressure we did not have the time to actually test it. And the question stayed in the back of my mind for some years. Reading about GRAKN, I was reminded of the the unanswered question, and decided to see I could actually make this work. And…spoiler alert: yes: it actually does.

GRAKN

GRAKN is not that well known, so a short introduction here makes sense. GRAKN is an open-source, distributed knowledge graph for knowledge-oriented systems. It is an evolution of the relational database for highly interconnected data as it provides a concept-level schema that fully implements the Entity-Relationship (ER) model. However, GRAKN’s schema is also type system that implements the principles of knowledge representation and reasoning. (source: Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GRAKN.AI). It’s the knowledge representation and reasoning that sets it apart. The representation is most accomplished through the GRAKN workbench, which, even though currently limited, already is an indispensable tool to enable a quick look at the stored information structure.

The reasoning capability is what made GRAKN interesting as a research topic to me. GRAKN has the ability to virtually add data to the graph based on rules, that you can define at any moment. This separates it from reasoning in most RDFS approaches, where the reasoning is done during ingress. This feature truly helps in adding meaning and knowledge to existing data, which we will see in the rest of this article.

If you are interested in the GRAKN environment itself: this is a good place to start.

Outline of this article

As stated in the introduction, the use-case has to do which multi-sourced data and the typical data quality processes around it. These are typical topics is today’s multi system design factories. What I will show first is the creation of the base data structure that describes a typical data set. Then, I’ll show how to load data into that set. This wille be some made up data, just to indicate the typical data. In a real life example of course this data will come from some kind of extraction program that gets it from the typical engineering systems.

After this step I’ll show the the way I engineered the rule. Finally this rule will be loaded in the data set, and I’ll show how we can measure the quality of the multi sourced data.

The main idea of data quality measuring is something that needs some explanation. The usual approach to this is to run some kind of rules or scripts over the data as is, to count the number of times that data that is not according to the rules. The approach here is different: using the rule system we add virtual data to the data set that indicates the erroneous data. A typical example is the situation where two systems contain the same object, but have different values for a given attribute. In that case a typed relation will be created between the two attributes that points out the difference. Measuring data quality in this case means just counting the number of these typed relations. This is attractive because, based on the way the data is structured, the creation of the type relations can be done for all attributes in one go, thus greatly simplifying the entire process. A second positive aspect is that, by identifying the erroneous information in this way the ‘repair’ process is also simplified: it is quite easy to point the user to the problem objects in follow-up steps.

As a side note, and for all of you coming up with the ‘What happened to the single source of the truth solution for this problem?’ question: please see my article on that topic. There is a case for this plan of attack as well.

Introducing

I’ll introduce the main players first: meet the data structure and the sample data-set.

Data structure

The data structure is made up out of 5 typical data elements and some data relations that are encountered in typical plant design processes.

PlantObject

A PlantObject is a something on a plant. Typical examples: pipe, pumps et cetera. For the model presented here, the PlantObject is represented only by an Identification code. In real world situations things like life-cycle information would probably also be a part of this part of the structure. However for our current example that is of no importance here, hence I’m not including any of that.

The GRAKN code for this is:

It basically introduces the PlantObject as a subclass from entity (which is the base class, much alike the Thing class in RDFS), states that it has a property ident, and that it can play a role in a relation, in which case it plays the role represents (more on this later). The ident attribute is then defined as a string. In real life situations probably some extension of the definition would be useful, like the declaration that the string has to be unique. However, for the sake of conciseness I’ll discard that topic for now.

SysPlantObject and System

The next objects types introduced are the SysPlantObject and the System object. Remember, in our example we expect the same data to be in multiple systems. The System object represents these systems. Example values could be values could be COMOS, E3D, Microstation et cetera, tools you would typically find in a plantdesign environment. The SysPlantObject is the pointer to the system specific representation of the PlantObject. So here we would find the PlantObject in the system specific version. Typically, here the expectation is that these objects in the system have the same identification, however in our data set they also have a specific code (name) to be able to identify them. The definition code is like this:

A new element here is the representation relation. It states that there is a three way relation between system, PlantObject and Sysplantobject. the roles of the relation (the representedby, represents, hasrepresentingsystem) are used to identify the objects types that can be part of the relation, see for example the PlantObject that take part in the represents role).

This part of the structure now looks like this:

Now that we have the SysPlantObject, representing PlantObject in a certain system, the next step is to add the attributes that we (later) want to check. For naming those I’m following the names used in the original book about Industrial ontologies: “Gellish, a generic extensible ontological language”, by Andries van Renssen. In that book these attributes are called aspects. Our code to add them to the structure is:

So we’re first creating an aspect definition entity, and it is this definition that allows us to handle all aspects (all attribute types) in the same way (this where the entire Proof of Concept relies on). The definition has a name (which has to be unique, but what we do not enforce in this example), it has a description, it has a type (what is meant is the datatype like string or real, et cetera) and finally it can play the role of property type in the relation that links an aspect to a sysplantobject.

The next thing to define is the actual aspect (this is where we define the value of the design aspect). It is tied to the relation that links the aspect definition to the sysplantobject, thereby enabling to add a value to an aspect definition that is a property of a sysplantobject.

After that the definitions of the attributes used in this part are defined.

This part of the schema now looks like this:

Then finally we’re coming the actual indication that there’s a pair of aspects that should be the same, is actually different. For this a simple relation is created:

This creates a relation is an alert for a two paired aspect values that are incorrect. It is the aspect that can play this role, as defined earlier (it plays the errorneousAspectValue role). Not that there is no reason to declare the two sides of the relation separately, even though they will link to different aspects. It is possible for each link of a relation to be used multiple times in a single relation instance.

Finally the entire schema looks like this:

Sample data

In this section I’ll discuss the actual insertion of the data in the GRAKN graph. The data is specifically created to illustrate the proof of the concept, so real data will definitely look different. However the indicated principle will in apply in use cases like this.

The source file for the data is available for download, see below in the download section.

In general there is a sequence of first deleting a object type, and then inserting it, this helped in reloading the data during development of this example.

The systems, PlantObject and SysPlantObject are loaded:

Then a series of representations is loaded:

They indicate the representations of the plant objects in the mentioned systems

Then, the design aspects are defined:

After this, the aspects are linked to the representing sysplantobjects as properties:

Everything else in the insert files can be ignored, these are remains of earlier experiments.

The Rule

For the rule to work I’ve added some inconsistencies in the loaded data-set:

Line 3 and 7 show a discrepancy, as do 13 and 18 and 23.

I’ve developed the rule by first creating a query that returns the erroneous objects:

Which results in the following result:

The interesting thing is that, although the results here show the error twice for each difference (from A to B and from B to A), when implemented as a rule, the relation is only made once (which is exactly what we want).

The Rule Implemented

Here’s the rule:

In production situations the debugging code, that was part of the original query should probably be removed.

Proving of the concept

Now, does it all work?

Screenshot from the GRAKN workbench:

Indeed we see the expected results. And note: there is no reference to any specific aspect in the code. This means the check will continue to work when we expand the aspect types.

Concluding notes

In the previous chapter the concept of generic data quality rules is proven to be feasible. In doing this, I learned that the graphical representation of the data is essential to be able to actuelly work work with it. Building a schema in GRAKN is different to building a schema in a relational database, because you do not get the structure that a relational database (like tables and keys) provides from the start. A second thing I discovered: the .gql language is quite harsh at the moment to work with. There are Java stack-traces when there is an error, difficult to understand error messages, etc. The way forward was found in creating the examples in very small steps and verifying each simple step before continuing with the next one. The example scripts from GRAKN themselves ( see here ) are quite helpful here as well.

Overall however, the GRAKN environment offers an unmatched functionality in knowledge representation in data rich environments.

Downloads

You can download the source files, if you want to experiment with this:

  • The Schema file
  • The Data file
  • The Rule definition

Alternative solutions

Peter Crocker writes in this article about RDFox, that allows reasoning in much the same way on RDF graphs.
entry.summary: Automated rule based discrepancy discovery by adding knowledge rules to an existing data set

entry.title: Sharing creates value
entry.content:
The positive effects of sharing in capital projects.

Sharing

This is an article in progress, however some in future articles I will detail I’ll already mention here as a kind of a preview. What I will show is that sharing (of information) seems in general to be a successful strategy when pursuing digitalization results. The question is not if, but mostly what should be share to create the best balance between giving away something and creating a financial result from that.

IPD

Integrated project delivery (as explained here) is a typical area where sharing (in this case of financial risks) creates value for all parties concerned.

BIM catalogs

Here again a sharing idea that delivers value: sharing the catalogs enables the parties sharing them to generate extra revenue, and it creates extra value for the customers of catalog parts because of the ease of ordering and the polished supply chain that follows the ordering process.

More examples

Will follow when this article matures.
entry.summary: The positive effects of sharing in capital projects.

entry.title: Capital project digitalization
entry.content:
PX-Alpha is about digital transformation in capital projects.

Digitalization

In general, digitization is defined along the lines of ‘…integration of digital technologies in everyday life..’ (see: http://www.businessdictionary.com/definition/digitalization.html). This is also my main view point for digitalization.

To generalize many other existing definitions a bit, digitalization is the process in which modern digital technologies are applied to existing business processes resulting in significant changes in the way value is created.

What makes digitalization so complex is that it is not only technology. To be successful, changes in business processes and business culture are required as well. In general, digitalization is a transformation in more than one area.
What this blog is all about: project information

And by definition: in capital projects the process involves the project parties, meaning the common understaning must be achieved over several seperate companies. In future articles an approach will be sketched that makes this process easier.

Being involved in these kind of changes, I’ve learned that in capital projects information integration is a key digitalization aspect. Integration inside the corporation or business unit, but especially between businesses and companies.

There are three reasons why integration is so valuable. Firstly the integration helps to break down the barriers between departments, functional areas and data silos. Secondly, the resulting integrated information can be used for analyses and improvement of data quality. Thirdly the integration of data between companies (by, for example, exchanging linked datasets, or using shared linked data resources) helps to ensure a common understanding of shared data which accellerates project execution.

Personally, I think that the actual sharing of data and information often is the key to successful digitalization initiatives. The modern technology, the increased competition and expected reduction in lead time and profit from sharing early in a controlled way.

In the future articles you will be able to find more detailed information about technology in the technology section, likewise the transformation aspect will have a separate section, containing articles on the topic.

About me and this website

PX-Alpha is a private endeavor beside my day job. You can contact me using this website’s contact page if you have questions in regard to designing digital transformation strategies, linked data, general IT strategies (if you still have them), identification of opportunities and real value-add solutions. I’m always interested in broadening my knowledge in these areas.

To generalize many other existing definitions a bit, digitalization is the process in which modern digital technologies are applied to existing business processes resulting in significant changes in the way value is created. What makes digitalization so complex is that it is not only technology. To be successful, changes in business processes and business culture are required as well. In general, digitalization is a transformation in more than one area. What this blog is all about: project information And by definition: in capital projects the process involves the project parties, meaning the common understaning must be achieved over several seperate companies. In future articles an approach will be sketched that makes this process easier. Being involved in these kind of changes, I’ve learned that in capital projects information integration is a key digitalization aspect. Integration inside the corporation or business unit, but especially between businesses and companies. There are three reasons why integration is so valuable. Firstly the integration helps to break down the barriers between departments, functional areas and data silos. Secondly, the resulting integrated information can be used for analyses and improvement of data quality. Thirdly the integration of data between companies (by, for example, exchanging linked datasets, or using shared linked data resources) helps to ensure a common understanding of shared data which accellerates project execution. Personally, I think that the actual sharing of data and information often is the key to successful digitalization initiatives. The modern technology, the increased competition and expected reduction in lead time and profit from sharing early in a controlled way. In the future articles you will be able to find more detailed information about technology in the technology section, likewise the transformation aspect will have a separate section, containing articles on the topic. You can contact me using this website’s contact page if you have questions in regard to designing digital transformation strategies, linked data, general IT strategies (if you still have them), identification of opportunities and real value-add solutions. I’m always interested in broadening my knowledge in these areas.

entry.title: This site
entry.content:
How this site was made

The making of this site

I thought it help me to remember what I’ve used for this site, in case I want to change things on it later. So here’s a list and description of what was used for it.1

Jekyll

The site is a Jekyll site. Jekyll is a framework to create static sites, so the only thing that is on the web-server are static HTML pages. Jekyll is a Ruby application that transforms the posts written in Markdown into the aforementioned HTML pages.
Read more: https://jekyllrb.com/, and on extending the Jekyll system without plugins: https://jekyllcodex.org/.

Markdown

The language in which the Jekyll pages are written.
Find a lot more here: https://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/syntax. And find (warning: geek-mode: on) markdown mode for Emacs: https://jblevins.org/projects/markdown-mode/.

Google fonts

I used Volkorn 2 for the initial character of the main post text.
Find it here: https://fonts.google.com/specimen/Vollkorn

What I used to make this work was

Some CSS and some more CSS, because the drop-caps are rendered differently in Chrome and in Firefox.
Some Kramdown IALs
A getting started with google fonts

Contact page

tbd

Page comments

Boy, that turned out to be much more complex than I expected it to be. I mean, how hard can this be in 2020? I tried several solutions, and finally settled on Commentics.

Commenting solutions that did not work out

I tried several solutions that, for various reasons, did not work out. I found several solutions here.

StaticMan

Find it here: https://staticman.net/ and more here https://www.vojtechruzicka.com/staticman/.3 StaticMan keeps your Jekyll site static, by pushing user comments to the GitHub site where your Jekyll code lives and updates the posts accordingly to the comments, by entering pull requests for them (I think, I never got to that point). What stopped me was the unclarity of the documentation: run this on Heroku? Or on GitHub? Which StaticManBot to use? And in which usage scenario? Anyway, I did not make it to get it into a working state.

HashOver

Find it here: https://www.barkdull.org/software/hashover. APHP solution to comments (my provider allows running PHP scripts). Got very confused about names of files and the contents of them (hashover.php in root folder is called /hashover/comment.php in documentation? There are differences between the .zip download and the GitHub repo?). Had to walk away, sorry for that.

Disqus

Find it here: https://disqus.com/.4 A hosted solution. Got it working quite quickly, however, as the solution is based on an iframe that is loaded from the disqus site, there is no way to style the comment area. And it looked horrible. A no-go.

The one that worked: Commentics

Find it here: https://www.commentics.org/. PHP based, easy install, worked right out if the box, even using the iframe setup, the comments area can be styled. Nice. Works well together with Jekyll. There is was, after one full day of work, a working comment solution.

What I learned along the way

Using PHP in a Jekyll site.

An interesting approach, that allows PHP inside Jekyll markup, but also Jekyll markup in PHP, read the article here: Running a combined Jekyll/PHP site on XAMPP by Christian Specht.

Heroku

I knew about Heroku as a Ruby hosting solution, but as a result of the StaticMan research I had a better look at it again. It’s not only Ruby, but all of the other main languages as well. Including CI/CD pipelines et cetera. This may be an interesting solution for future development work.
